title: Indians hoping to move on from tough losses on, off field
text:
Indians hoping to move on from tough losses on, off field by Comments 
East Coweta head football coach Steve Pardue had every reason to be disappointed last weekend. 
The Indians dropped their first game of the season to Langston Hughes, and East Coweta was hit with key injuries to junior quarterback Will LaGuardia and senior linebacker Alec Jimerson. 
LaGuardia took a hard blow that knocked his helmet off last week, and isn’t expected to play in tonight’s Homecoming battle with Pebblebrook at Garland Shoemake Stadium. The news is even more grim for Jimerson, who suffered torn ligaments in his knee that will end his varsity career following upcoming surgery. 
But East Coweta (5-1, 2-1 in Region 3- ) still has plenty to play for in its final four region games while still in the thick of the playoff race. The Indians are now tied with Newnan and Westlake in the loss column while one game behind Hughes, which still has to play both 
the Cougars and Lions this year. East Coweta has already defeated Westlake and can equally gain a head-to-head tiebreaker in its annual meeting with Newnan on Oct. 30 at Drake Stadium. 
First, however, the Indians need to take care of business tonight against a much improved Pebblebrook lineup. Last week, the Falcons (3-3, 1-2) won its first region game since moving into 3- in 2013, defeating Cobb rival Campbell 27-6 at home while in its first sea- son under head coach Kevin Saunders. 
Despite allowing a season-high 29 points at Langston Hughes last week, the Indians loss came down to a poor third-quarter that allowed the Panthers to pounce for a pair of scoring drives. 
“The only difference between winning and losing is Saturday,” Pardue said. “If you win on Friday, you are happy on Saturday, if you lose, you are not.” 
The veteran coach is also not bothered with the off-field festivities that come with homecoming that some may feel can be a distraction. 
“I don’t mind homecoming,” he said. “It’s a little bit different, but I want our kids to enjoy it. They know there are things that they have to get done, but they need to have fun.” 
With Jimerson out of the lineup, the Indians have lost one of their most vocal leaders. 
“You have really feel for Alec,” Pardue said. “He is really one of leaders and to get hurt like that your senior year is awful.” 
On the other side of the ball, East Coweta has a capable fill-in for LaGuardia at quarterback. Sophomore Christian Reid, who gained playing time in a blowout win over Whitewater, scored two late touchdowns after enter- ing the game for his teammate in the second half. 
“I think our kids have a really good attitude this week,” Pardue said. “I don’t think our preparation was as good as it could have been last week. I think we have their attention this week.” 
Pebblebrook (3-3, 1-2) comes into the contest fresh off a 27-6 victory over Campbell to snap a two-game losing streak. 
It was also the Falcons first region win in 10 games.
